intro: Raphionacme scandens, commonly known as the climbing bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the eastern United States. It features slender, climbing stems that can reach lengths of up to 6 feet, often twining around other plants or structures. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically blue or violet in color, with five lobes and a distinctive spurred structure at the base. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and have a slightly hairy texture. Raphionacme scandens thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodland areas or along stream banks.
